text: <@UJ48Q1HAP> I’m also interested in the idea of a research team :heart_eyes:… we’d love to scale our writing, but a roadblock is how much original data/info we have, vs. what we can scrounge from already-written blog posts. Could you share a bit about how they operate?

elements.text: I’m also interested in the idea of a research team
… we’d love to scale our writing, but a roadblock is how much original data/info we have, vs. what we can scrounge from already-written blog posts. Could you share a bit about how they operate?

text: <@U018Q693YRF> The most important thing I think the team has done over the past 6 months or so is build out a list of "recommended sources" - almost like "recommended vendors" where we know we can go for reliable info related to the subjects we cover. (Which, since we're an agency, can be pretty much anything)

elements.text: The most important thing I think the team has done over the past 6 months or so is build out a list of "recommended sources" - almost like "recommended vendors" where we know we can go for reliable info related to the subjects we cover. (Which, since we're an agency, can be pretty much anything)

text: We've got a "hierarchy" of sorts as far as those sources: OG research (Census, studies, etc.) is at the top, then reports by reputable research/consulting organizations (your McKinseys and such), plus reputable pubs (Bloomberg, WSJ, Financial Times, etc.), tech blogs (TechCrunch etc.), subject-matter-specific blogs, and at the VERY bottom social (but only for sourcing direct quotes/opinions/general sentiment about a topic)

elements.text: We've got a "hierarchy" of sorts as far as those sources: OG research (Census, studies, etc.) is at the top, then reports by reputable research/consulting organizations (your McKinseys and such), plus reputable pubs (Bloomberg, WSJ, Financial Times, etc.), tech blogs (TechCrunch etc.), subject-matter-specific blogs, and at the VERY bottom social (but only for sourcing direct quotes/opinions/general sentiment about a topic)

text: ^ that structure makes for a pretty repeatable research flow, even though the specific asks of a given research project (and the specific sources it makes sense to consult) may vary.

elements.text: ^ that structure makes for a pretty repeatable research flow, even though the specific asks of a given research project (and the specific sources it makes sense to consult) may vary.

text: But it still saves our writers a ton of time to be able to put together a brief covering what kind of info they need to fill out the post, go off and write something else in the meantime, and come back to a list of reputable, pre-vetted sources

elements.text: But it still saves our writers a ton of time to be able to put together a brief covering what kind of info they need to fill out the post, go off and write something else in the meantime, and come back to a list of reputable, pre-vetted sources

text: That’s really interesting, thanks for sharing <@UJ48Q1HAP>! We used to have an internal document like that with a curated selection of research matching our most frequently covered topics, but didn’t have the ongoing investment of a specific team to help.

elements.text: That’s really interesting, thanks for sharing
! We used to have an internal document like that with a curated selection of research matching our most frequently covered topics, but didn’t have the ongoing investment of a specific team to help.

text:
Agency here. Hm. Re: Freelancers, often it’s a specific statement of work for one client of ours, so there’s no mystery about what needs to be done. The workload expectations are clear. X pieces per month, delivered biweekly, or something like that.

Howevah, your timing is curious here. I’m preparing to offer a 3-6 month writing contract to someone, but am trying to come up a fair rate that reflects anticipated workload from multiple clients. I don’t want them to be idle, nor do I want to overload them. Hard to account for such variability in a contract.
